nodes.text: A face recognition system based on Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and the eigenface approach can efficiently recognize human faces in constrained environments
PCA reduces dimensionality by representing each training image as a linear combination of eigenvectors (eigenfaces) derived from the covariance matrix of the training set
Recognition is performed by projecting a test image onto the eigenface subspace and classifying by minimum Euclidean distance between weight vectors
The eigenface method is simple, fast, insensitive to small or gradual facial changes, and suitable when images are frontal and similarly scaled

Method: Prepare training set by centering and vectorizing same-size face images, compute average face vector, subtract mean to form matrix A, compute covariance matrix C = A A transpose, and obtain eigenfaces from the largest eigenvalues
Method refinement: compute eigenvectors of the smaller MxM matrix L = A transpose A, then derive the M largest eigenvectors of C to form the eigenface basis, and keep top K eigenvectors
Method: For each training or test image compute feature weights by projecting the mean-subtracted image onto the K eigenfaces to obtain a weight vector
Result: Classification is done by computing Euclidean distances between the test image weight vector and all training weight vectors; the minimum distance identifies the closest face class
Experimental setup: Implementation in MATLAB using ETE-07 series RUET database with 36 images of 18 persons, images of size 200x149 pixels
Evidence: Experiments showed successful recognition of human faces under different face orientations and on Bitmap, PNG, and JPEG images, with good classification in constrained conditions
Limitation: The eigenface method requires frontal, similarly scaled images and has reduced performance with variation in image size and unconstrained pose/lighting
Assumption: Training images are centered, of the same size, and sufficiently representative so that the top K eigenfaces capture characteristic facial features

Conclusion: The PCA eigenface approach provides a practical, fast, and relatively simple solution for face recognition in constrained environments but needs further work for varying image sizes and real-time video
Future work: Extend the system to real-time video, use much larger databases, address varying image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other face recognition methods
